nodes.text: A systematic experimental comparison of commonly used feature selection methods can guide selection of appropriate feature selection techniques for text classification
We conducted comparative experiments evaluating twenty typical feature selection methods on four benchmark text datasets using decision tree classifiers and 10-fold cross validation
The four datasets (CARR, COMD, IMDB, KDCN) were chosen from the UCI repository to cover diverse domains (cars, companies, movies, Turkish news) and have prior use in published text mining work

The twenty feature selection methods compared include supervised scores (IG, ECE, MI, GI, IGI, CHI variants, OR variants, MOR, MC-OR, etc.) and unsupervised frequency/variance methods (DF, TF, TV, TVQ, MM, AMGM, MAD)
Supervised methods use class information to score terms while unsupervised methods use frequency statistics of document-term matrix
Experimental results (DT accuracy vs number of selected terms) show consistent performance patterns across datasets allowing ranking of methods
MOR and MC-OR achieved the best classification accuracies among all compared methods
IGI achieved near-best performance while having a simpler formula and easier implementation compared to MOR and MC-OR
Unsupervised variance and frequency methods TV, TVQ, TF and DF achieved relatively good performance and are preferable when computational efficiency is a priority
ECE performs well in most cases but performs poorly when selecting a small number of terms (for example 20 or 50)
AMGM, MM and MAD showed unstable performance across datasets, with particularly poor results for AMGM on KDCN and for MM and MAD on CARR
IG, GI and MI produced the worst classification accuracies among the compared methods, with MI max-version outperforming MI average-version
EOR and WOR methods performed slightly better than the poorest group (IG, GI, MI) but worse than the top and middle-ranked methods
Conclusion: MOR and MC-OR are the best choices for accuracy; IGI is a practical alternative balancing accuracy and simplicity; TV/TVQ/TF/DF are preferred when efficiency matters
Supervised top-performing methods (MOR, MC-OR, IGI) require computing term-class distributions and therefore have higher computational cost than unsupervised methods
